div.head: General Remarks
div.p: Information on the quire structure is encoded in collationwith a list of item elements for each quire. See this example from BAVet91:

Each item has an attribute xml:id with a value "q" followed by the consecutive number that indicates the physical position of the quire in the manuscript. This allows to refer to each particular quire. The element dim with unit="leaf" indicates the number of leaves within the quire while the locus element contains information on the quire's boundaries.
Each item can also have the attribute n with a consecutive numeral as a value

div.head: Encoding the quire structure
div.p: The leaves of the quire are counted from left to right, over the centrefold, and referred to with the numbers 1, 2, 3, 4, etc.

The number of leaves in the quire is normally even, but can frequently also be odd (1, 3, 5, etc.). In this case, it is necessary to indicate the positions of each single leaf and its stub (the short part of the leaf that "hooks" it into the textblock), in relation to the other leaves of the quire. This can be recorded in the following way:
(number of the single leaf), stub before (number of the leaf following the stub)
(number of the single leaf), stub after (number of the leaf preceding the stub)
In some cases (esp. if you work on images), no stub can be detected. This can be recorded as:
(number of the single leaf), no stub
5
2, stub after 4
…
The quire can include two or more single leaves even if the total number is even:

An unbalanced quire with an uneven number of leaves in dim always needs clarification. You have to indicate which leaf is single using the formulas for the single leaf and its stub as stated above. No quire structure will be visualized if only the following is given:

div.head: Flyleaves
div.p: If the manuscript contains flyleaf (protective) quires, their presence may be indicated by adapting the value of n with the value "q" followed by the letters "A" for a flyleaf quire at the beginning of the manuscript and "B" at the end of the manuscript:

div.head: Encoding of further features
div.p:
Further features of the quire structure can be encoded with the help of the following terms:
replaced
missing
added
These allow you to indicate that the quire was disturbed and one leaf was taken out of it or added into it; you can explain more on the nature or cause of this modification in a note (for instance that the leaf was cut, torn off etc.).

For instance, to show that a quire of 9 leaves represents originally a 10-leave quire (quinion) that lost one leaf, you write as follows (indicating not the real but the reconstructed number of leaves in dim):
…
10 1 missing, stub after 9
…
A descriptive explanation concerning any further feature of the specific quire can be introduced in note which should be placed after the information on any single leaves, if occurring:

collation.list:
…
3
2, stub after 1 Leaves 1 and 3 of irregular shape
…

div.p: Sometimes you might also need to describe the position of a quire using locus elements. Please, also do this in a note, as the locus element is here reserved for the quire extent.

div.head: Quire marks
div.p:
Precise information on the quire signatures/marks written by the scribes can be stated by means of the element num with value:
…
፳ 8
…

The presence, absence and further properties of quire marks (usually Ethiopic numerals assigned by the manuscript-makers to quires, to keep the sequence) such as location, structure, decoration or hand can be described in the signatures element in collation, summarily or one by one:

collation.signatures: Undecorated quire marks are written in the main hand, in the middle of the upper margin of , ….

div.head: Composite manuscripts
div.p: In composite manuscripts, collation can be added to the first physDesc that pertains to the entire manuscript, to each individual msPart or to both. It is up to the encoder to decide which place is more fitting.

div.head: General or fragmentary information on the quire structure
div.p: Many catalogues do not provide any information on the quire structure. Sometimes it is only possible to provide general information or fragmentary observations on the quire structure. Sometimes the information is imprecise and can be ascertained only by means of a direct check of the physical manuscript. In any case, all available data of whatever kind can be summarized in a note inside collation, as in this example from BDLaethf7:

collation.note: The textual sequence of the manuscript is disturbed, see .

div.head: Visualisation (diagrams and quire formula)
div.p: Here the ways in which the correctly encoded quire structure is currently visualised on the web application are explained. As always, please do not let your encoding diverge from these guidelines in order to produce another visualisation. If you wish for another visualisation or encounter problems while encoding that are not covered by these guidelines, please open an issue.

All information encoded in this way will be visualized. Added leaves are shown with hyphens, replaced leaves are dot-hyphen lines (stubs are not shown currently). In addition to that, the same information expressed in the Ethio-SPaRe formula will appear below.
